```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```
:::

# Setup

First, let's load our packages and read in the data.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(readxl)

LungCapData <- read_xls("_data/LungCapData.xls")
```
:::



# Section 1
`
## Q1a

What does the distribution of LungCap look like?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lcdata %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=LungCap)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x="Lung Capacity", y="Frequency")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in ggplot(., aes(x = LungCap)): object 'lcdata' not found
```
:::
:::



The histogram suggests that the distribution is close to a normal distribution. Most of the observations are close to the mean. Very few observations are close to the margins (0 and 15).

## Q1b

Compare the probability density of the LungCap with respect to Males and Females.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lcdata %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=LungCap)) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(group=Gender, color=Gender)) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme (axis.text.y = element_blank ())
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in ggplot(., aes(x = LungCap)): object 'lcdata' not found
```
:::
:::

The boxplot comparison incdicates that on average males have more lung capacity, but it also shows that the range for each gender is extremely similar and with a lot of overlap.

## Q1c

Compare the mean lung capacities for smokers and non-smokers. Does it make sense?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lcdata %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=LungCap)) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(color=Smoke))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in ggplot(., aes(x = LungCap)): object 'lcdata' not found
```
:::
:::


Comparing the distributions shows that Smokers have a higher mean lung capacity and a significantly smaller range and IQR. This does not make sense intuitively so I would want to investigate the data a bit more to understand the possible reasons for this.

## Q1d

Examine the relationship between Smoking and Lung Capacity within age groups: "less than or equal to 13", "14 to 15", "16 to 17", and "greather than or equal to 18". 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lcdata %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=Age,y=LungCap,color=Smoke)) +
  geom_point(alpha=0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in ggplot(., aes(x = Age, y = LungCap, color = Smoke)): object 'lcdata' not found
```
:::
:::


## Q1e

Compare the lung capacities for smokers and non-smokers  within each age group. Is your answer different from the one in part d? What could possibly be going on here?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
lc_with_age_groups <- lcdata %>%
  mutate(Age_Group = factor(case_when(
    Age <= 13 ~ "<=13",
    Age %in% c(14,15) ~ "14-15",
    Age %in% c(16,17) ~ "16-17",
    Age >= 18 ~ ">=18"
      ),
    levels = c("<=13","14-15","16-17",">=18")
    )
  )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in mutate(., Age_Group = factor(case_when(Age <= 13 ~ "<=13", Age %in% : object 'lcdata' not found
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
lc_with_age_groups %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=Smoke, y=LungCap, color=Age_Group)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~Age_Group)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in ggplot(., aes(x = Smoke, y = LungCap, color = Age_Group)): object 'lc_with_age_groups' not found
```
:::
:::
